data.title: John Lee Hooker (abt.1917-2001)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Explore genealogy for John Hooker born abt. 1917 Tutwiler, Tallahatchie, Mississippi, United States died 2001 Los Alto. California, United States including father + 2 photos + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
[spouse(s) unknown]

[children unknown]

Profile last modified 20 Dec 2023 | Created 13 Dec 2020

This page has been accessed 768 times.

Contents

1 Biography

1.1 Career

1.2 Honors and Awards

1.3 Personal Life

2 Research Notes

3 Sources

Biography

John Hooker is Notable.

John Hooker was featured in Blues Hall of Fame, 1980.

John Lee Hooker was an American blues singer, songwriter and guitarist.[1]

John Lee Hooker was born about 1917 to William Hooker (1872-) and Minnie Ramsey near Tutwiler, Mississippi (or possibly near Clarksdale, Coahoma, Mississippi).[2][3] His father was a farmer and a Baptist minister. In 1921, his parents separated and a year later his mother married William Moore, a blues singer. John went to live with his mother and began to learn blues guitar from his step-father.

At age 14, John left home to venture out on his own. Although born in the Mississippi Delta, his blues guitar playing took on a unique style from the influence of Will Moore who had come from Louisiana. John eked out a living as a musician and taking on odd jobs in Memphis and Cinncinati before heading to Detroit in the early 1940s.

Career

In Detroit, his musical career took off. John switched from acoustic to electric guitar. His "boogie" beat style became popular with his first hit song in 1949, "Boogie Chillen," which became No. 1 on the R & B charts. In 1951, his song, "I'm in the Mood," also hit No. 1.

Honors and Awards

1980 induction into the Blues Hall of Fame

1991 induction into the Rock 'n Roll Hall of Fame

Grammy Awards:

Best Traditional Blues Recording for I'm in the Mood with Bonnie Raitt, 1990

Best Traditional Blues Album for Chill Out, 1995

Best Traditional Blues Recording for Don't Look Back, 1998

Best Pop Collaboration with Vocals for Don't Look Back with Van Morrison, 1998

Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award, 2000

1999 Rhythm and Blues Foundation Pioneer Award

Mississippi Musicians Hall of Fame

Other honors: Los Angeles' Rock Walk, Bammies Walk of Fame in San Francisco, a star in the Hollywood Walk of Fame (1997), and a plaque in his honor, located in Vance, Mississippi, along the Mississippi Blues Trail. He was inducted into the Mississippi Musicians Hall of Fame. [4]

Personal Life

He was married to Alma Hope[5]

He was married to Maude Mathis[6]

He was married to Freda Dolores Lyons [7]

He was married to Sarah Jones [no sources for this marriage found yet]

At the time of his death in 2001, he had eight surviving children.[8]

Research Notes

John Lee Hooker's date of birth is uncertain. The U.S. Census records show the following:

1920 -- age 7 (born abt. 1913)

1930 -- age 18 (abt. 1912)

1940 -- age 24 (abt. 1916)

1950 -- age 32 (abt. 1918)

1940 U.S. World War II Draft Card: 25 Aug 1914

1962 marriage record: age 39 on 22 Aug 1961 (born 22 Aug 1922)

There is also some controversy about his place of birth:

1920 and 1930 U.S. Censuses show his family living near Tutwiler, Mississippi

1940 U.S. World War II Draft Card: born in Glendora, Mississippi

1962 marriage record: born in Clarksdale, Mississippi

he apparently claimed to be born between Clarksdale and Vance, Mississippi (See: https://www.hmdb.org/m.asp?m=174054)
